title: David Gregory (Royal Navy officer)
text:
<a href="Vice%20admiral%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">Vice Admiral</a> Sir George David Archibald Gregory & <a href="Medal%20bar">Bar</a> (8 October 1909 – 21 March 1975) was a <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> officer who became <a href="Flag%20Officer%20Scotland%2C%20Northern%20England%2C%20Northern%20Ireland">Flag Officer, Scotland and Northern Ireland</a>.
Naval career.
Gregory became a <a href="sub-lieutenant">sub-lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> in 1930. He served in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> as Commanding Officer of the <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s and and the <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> . In a single action in September 1940 HMS "Sturgeon" <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed an enemy transport ship with the loss of 4,000 German troops. He was appointed <a href="Commodore-in-Charge%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Commodore-in-Charge, Hong Kong</a> from March 1957 to April 1960. He was next appointed <a href="Admiral%20Superintendent%20Devonport">Admiral-Superintendent, Devonport</a> in 1960, and <a href="Flag%20Officer%20Scotland%2C%20Northern%20England%2C%20Northern%20Ireland">Flag Officer, Scotland and Northern Ireland</a> in 1964 before retiring in 1966.
